xxl.core.cursors
Class DecoratorCursor<E>

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.cursors.DecoratorCursor<E>
Type Parameters:
E - the type of the elements returned by this iteration.
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.util.Iterator<E>, Cursor<E>, Decorator<Cursor<E>>
Direct Known Subclasses:
AutomaticCloseCursor, LoggingMetaDataCursor
public abstract class DecoratorCursor<E>
extends java.lang.Object
implements Cursor<E>, Decorator<Cursor<E>>

This class decorates an object implementing the interface Cursor such that all method calls on the decorator are passed to its decorated object. For these purposes it realizes the design pattern, named Decorator. The intent of this design pattern is to attach additional responsibilities to an object dynamically. So decorators provide a flexible alternative to subclassing for extending functionality. For further information see: "Gamma et al.: DesignPatterns. Elements of Reusable Object-Oriented Software. Addision Wesley 1998."

Note: When the given input iteration only implements the interface Iterator it is wrapped to a cursor by a call to the static method wrap.

See Also:
Iterator, Cursor

Field Detail

cursor

protected Cursor<E> cursor
The decorated cursor that is used for passing method calls to.

Constructor Detail

DecoratorCursor

public DecoratorCursor(java.util.Iterator<E> iterator)
Creates a new decorator-cursor. The given iterator is wrapped to a cursor by calling the method Cursors.wrap(java.util.Iterator) and all method calls are finally passed to it.

Parameters:
iterator - the iterator to be decorated.
Method Detail

open

public void open()
Opens the cursor, i.e., signals the cursor to reserve resources, open files, etc. Before a cursor has been opened calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Therefore open must be called before a cursor's data can be processed. Multiple calls to open do not have any effect, i.e., if open was called the cursor remains in the state opened until its close method is called.

Note, that a call to the open method of a closed cursor usually does not open it again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

Specified by:
open in interface Cursor<E>

close

public void close()
Closes the cursor, i.e., signals the cursor to clean up resources, close files, etc. When a cursor has been closed calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Multiple calls to close do not have any effect, i.e., if close was called the cursor remains in the state closed.

Note, that a closed cursor usually cannot be opened again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

Specified by:
close in interface Cursor<E>

hasNext

public boolean hasNext()
                throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
Returns true if the iteration has more elements. (In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)

This operation is implemented idempotent, i.e., consequent calls to hasNext do not have any effect.

Specified by:
hasNext in interface java.util.Iterator<E>
Specified by:
hasNext in interface Cursor<E>
Returns:
true if the cursor has more elements.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the cursor is already closed when this method is called.

peek

public E peek()
       throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
Shows the next element in the iteration without proceeding the iteration (optional operation).

Note, that this operation is optional and might not work for all cursors. After calling the peek method a call to next is strongly recommended.

Specified by:
peek in interface Cursor<E>
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the cursor is already closed when this method is called.

supportsPeek

public boolean supportsPeek()
Returns true if the peek operation is supported by the cursor. Otherwise it returns false.

Specified by:
supportsPeek in interface Cursor<E>
Returns:
true if the peek operation is supported by the cursor, otherwise false.

remove

public void remove()
Removes from the underlying data structure the last element returned by the cursor (optional operation).

Note, that this operation is optional and might not work for all cursors.

Specified by:
remove in interface java.util.Iterator<E>

update

public void update(E object)
Replaces the last element returned by the cursor in the underlying data structure (optional operation).

Note, that this operation is optional and might not work for all cursors.

Specified by:

Specified by:

Returns:
true if the update operation is supported by the cursor, otherwise false.

reset

public void reset()
Resets the cursor to its initial state such that the caller is able to traverse the underlying data structure again without constructing a new cursor (optional operation). The modifications, removes and updates concerning the underlying data structure, are still persistent.

Note, that this operation is optional and might not work for all cursors.

Specified by:
reset in interface Cursor<E>

supportsReset

public boolean supportsReset()
Returns true if the reset operation is supported by the cursor. Otherwise it returns false.

Specified by:
supportsReset in interface Cursor<E>
Returns:
true if the reset operation is supported by the cursor, otherwise false.

getDecoree

public Cursor<E> getDecoree()
Returns the cursor decorated by this decorator cursor, that is used for passing method calls to. Note that is returned cursor and the iterator submitted at construction time are usually not the same, because the submitted iterator will be wrapped by a call to the method Cursors.wrap(java.util.Iterator).

Specified by:
getDecoree in interface Decorator<Cursor<E>>
Returns:
the cursor decorated by this decorator cursor.
